Instrument.name: Solar Wind Observations Over the Poles of the Sun for ULY
Instrument.description: The Solar Wind Plasma Experiment on the Ulysses spacecraft is designed to comprehensively analyze the interplanetary plasma's bulk flow and internal conditions as it travels towards Jupiter and beyond. The experiment utilizes curved-plate electrostatic analyzers and Channel Electron Multipliers (CEMs) to measure solar wind electrons and ions across a range of energies and angles. Specifically, it detects electrons from 0.86 eV to 814 eV and ions from 255 eV/q to 34.4 keV/q, collecting data every 4 to 8 minutes depending on the spacecraft's activity. The instrumentation allows for detailed characterization of velocity distributions and adapts to changes in solar wind intensity and direction using a variety of command-controlled measurement configurations. The system is also capable of resolving heavy ions under optimal conditions.
